thread.title: This is what Sunderland need to secure Premier League survival - David Moyes
thread.title_full: This is what Sunderland need to secure Premier League survival - David Moyes

title: This is what Sunderland need to secure Premier League survival - David Moyes
text:
Published 26th February 2017 
GETTY David Moyes' Sunderland have spent 175 days in the relegation zone - more than any other club 
The Black Cats boss laid out his target o avoid relegation after they suffered another blow to their chances at Moyes’ former club. 
Moyes believes his team need a total of 10 wins but with only five in the bank so far knows the Premier League’s bottom side face an uphill task. 
He said: “I’ve an idea that I’m going to have to win about 10 games to give myself any chance so I’ve got a bit of work to do between now and the end of the season. 
“I just believe that we’ll get a good run somewhere along the line. I don’t think it’s too late. 
David Moyes’ former Everton and Manchester United army at Sunderland Monday, 30th January 2017 SUNDERLAND boss David Moyes has brought in yet more of his ex-Everton and Manchester United players. 1 / 11 David Moyes’ former Everton and Manchester United army at Sunderland “I’ve got to believe it’s going to happen” Sunderland boss David Moyes 
“We’ve got a tough run - the next game is Man City so I’m not kidding myself. We’re in a couple of games where we just have to stick with it. 
“But I think Sunderland have been in a lower state than this and come from behind. I still believe there’s a run. 
“The way football works sometimes is that you never see it coming. So I’ve got to believe it’s going to happen.” 
Moyes had a clear plan of which games he had a chance of winning when he saved Everton from the drop in 2002. 
He has a similar road map of how to navigate Sunderland out of trouble and insists a visit to Goodison was not a game he was expecting to get anything from. 
But it could have been at least in the bag had a bit of luck gone their way. 
Idrissa Gueye put Everton ahead five minutes before half-time when he lashed home from Seamus Coleman’s cut back for his first goal for the club. 
Jermain Defoe smashed a shot off the underside of the bar in the 78th minute and 120 seconds later Romelu Lukaku broke away before finding the net via a deflection off former Toffee Bryan Oviedo to kill the game. 
“We are lacking quality at times that I hope would give us a chance or a goal,” Moyes added. Related videos
